chunks.en: Staying in a company for twelve years, almost 35, where should I go?

Let me start by describing my situation: I'm a C++ programmer in the computer industry (non-internet), almost 35 years old, working for a private company (with poor performance), located in Hangzhou, married with one child, owning a house and two cars, no debt, and have 3 million in cash flow due to demolition compensation.
The company is within five kilometers of my home, and there's no traffic, so it definitely takes less than fifteen minutes to drive there.

I earn around 200k a year. The company pays the five insurances and one housing fund based on a lower base (which I don't mind). My wife earns a little less than me, but her company benefits are good, so including the housing fund, she actually earns more than me.
Neither of us are into intense work or pushing our child, so we don't work 996, we go to work and leave on time, and the company isn't strict about taking leave.
I joined this company after graduation, mainly focusing on C++, and I also dabble in front-end development. I'm good at being a code monkey.

I'm not very ambitious. Maybe I've seen too many people come and go, so I don't have any desire for promotion. I've always been a foot soldier, but at least I can support one of the company's business lines.
In the past few years of the pandemic, I've felt that the company is declining, and they basically haven't been giving out year-end bonuses.

This year is even worse, with everyone's salary being cut. I want to leave (it can't be worse than it is now, and my salary requirements are very low), but looking at the dismal job market, as well as considering the commute and taking leave, I feel that I'm almost 35. Based on my personal situation (no interview experience, lack of communication skills), finding a job with good benefits will definitely require overtime.
Should I continue to endure it?
Or should I reluctantly let go and look for a job with better benefits, but face greater transition costs and pressure?
V friends, please give me some advice. I'm very confused.
A house, two cars, no debt, and 3 million in cash flow, I've never fought such a rich battle.
Damn, just whining about nothing.
Whining about nothing.
What's with this stupid post? Isn't the demolition compensation in RMB?
What do you mean your whole family 'only' has 400k besides the demolition money, with a house, car, no debt, a wife, kids, and parents, and you're still not satisfied?
I suggest you just jump off a building and be reborn.
Whining about nothing.
Hurry up and become a delivery driver, your situation is already very dangerous.
Give me 1.5 million of your cash flow, and then buy two more houses. Won't that give you pressure and motivation?

chunks.en: Maybe many people don't have a concept of 3 million: I calculated that both my wife and I are in the internet industry, and starting from the low salary the year we graduated, after 10 years of working together, we don't have 3 million in cash, and we are still in the so-called high-paying industry (of course, not top programmer income). 2 people * 10 years = 20 years of youth, OP you have saved 20 years of hard work, why bother, there are only a few 10 years in a life.
What bad luck made me click on this bragging post during my unlucky work hours, hoping to find some resonance?
It's true that you lack a basic understanding of society since you joined one company after graduation.

Regardless of the fact that you keep emphasizing the lucky demolition compensation of 3 million in cash flow, just the fact that you have a house in Hangzhou with no debt, how dare you position yourself as below average?
How can other users reconcile this?
I can only complain that you're showing off.

People need to constantly improve their self-awareness. You emphasize that you're not ambitious on the one hand, and on the other hand, you're tired of the current comfortable environment. This cognitive dissonance is too common for restless animals like humans.
There are too many scenarios in life where you're eating from your bowl while looking at the pot. A 35-year-old should understand that this is more of a sign of restlessness.
Seriously understand yourself, do you want to live a comfortable life or a more exciting and fulfilling life experience?
A 35-year-old should have some immunity to short-sighted and impulsive scenarios, and should try to think about problems in a more long-term and in-depth way.

If it were me, I would already be planning my retirement. Isn't it good to enjoy life? What kind of pressure do you have? You're still comparing yourself to your peers and feeling a bit inferior. You're already 35, don't you understand that life doesn't need to be compared to anyone? Just live comfortably. You have enough money now, why do you have to make yourself unhappy?
Wait to be laid off and get severance.
Why do such hard work when you have 3 million?

Reduce your material desires, live off the interest, and then deliver 20 orders of food delivery every day to enrich yourself. You can communicate with strangers and exercise. You won't have to worry about food and life in the second half of your life. Only a healthy body and no stress can lead to longevity. But seeing your idea of wanting to be a short-lived labor slave, I can't persuade you, and I can't give you any advice.
Whining about nothing.
At this moment, I really hope that v2 had a downvote feature.

'Entrepreneurship is a practice in life, a game for the brave. If you have a dream and passion, then bravely pursue it and put it into practice.' - Li Ka-shing 'Everyone has their own stage, and entrepreneurship allows you to perform to your heart's content on this stage.' - Ma Huateng 'Entrepreneurship is like skydiving, only by jumping out bravely can you have the opportunity to fly higher and further.' - Lei Jun 'Entrepreneurship is a way of life, a pursuit of self-challenge and growth.' - Liu Qiangdong 'If you have an idea, then implement it, don't worry about failure, because failure is the necessary path to success.' - Richard Branson 'Entrepreneurship is an adventure, but it is this spirit of adventure that gives us the opportunity to create great undertakings.' - Ma Yun 'If you have a dream and believe it can be realized, then bravely pursue it and don't let your dream become a regret.' - Steve Jobs
@seanwhy If you are only dissatisfied with your salary, then continue working.
If you deposit 3 million in a fixed deposit with a 3% interest rate, you will get 90,000 a year, plus you and your wife's income is already a lot.
Every company has its own problems, and you may be even more dissatisfied if you change companies, although the money may increase.
@Rrrrrr I think you are sick, and not just mildly.

I won't maliciously speculate on the purpose of the poster's post. I've read through 2 pages of comments, and judging from some of the poster's descriptions, the poster is actually quite humble, and feels that the 3 million wasn't obtained through their own ability, and is not very confident in their own abilities~
Actually, you can think about it from a different perspective, and treat it as a gift from life. You should know that the vast majority of people don't have such an opportunity~
Since you have received this gift from God, think about how to play your cards well, make good use of it, and don't let some negative thoughts deepen your feelings of 'inferiority'~
The reason people are confused is because they don't know what they want~

If you feel dissatisfied with your current job and have various worries, and the external environment is volatile and unstable, relying on your fairly solid family background, set a long-term plan for yourself, such as what you want to do in 1-2 years, and use this to deduce what you should do~

If you change jobs (short-term plan), even if you find a job in the next six months, the novelty in the new job will be difficult to sustain for long. Perhaps you are just jumping from one fire pit to another, and it is too difficult to get rich or achieve financial freedom by working~
You already have a good starting point compared to most people. As long as you don't mess around, you also have more opportunities to 'trial and error' and start over than most people~

chunks.en: As for what you should do, no one can give you the answer. You can only rely on yourself to think about it. You can even not be a programmer. Anything is possible~ğŸ‘ Cheer up, poster ğŸ˜„

OP says he didn't come to brag, he gets about 300 in interest per day from large certificates of deposit, and his wife also earns more than him, and then he sincerely (or hypocritically) asks for help from V users who are 99.99% not doing as well as him.
